title: Esther Chapter 4 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Esther chapter 4 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Esther Chapter 4 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Esther Chapter 4.

questions.question: What did Mordecai do when he perceived all that was done?
options: Rent his clothes and put on sackcloth with ashes
Went to the king's palace to speak
Sent a message to Esther
Fled the city
questions.correctAnswer: Rent his clothes and put on sackcloth with ashes
questions.explanation: Esther 4:1 states that Mordecai rent his clothes and put on sackcloth with ashes when he perceived all that was done.

questions.question: Where did Mordecai go after putting on sackcloth and ashes?
options: Into the midst of the city
To the king's throne room
To Esther's chambers
To the temple
questions.correctAnswer: Into the midst of the city
questions.explanation: According to Esther 4:1, Mordecai went out into the midst of the city after putting on sackcloth and ashes.

questions.question: Why could Mordecai not enter the king's gate clothed with sackcloth?
options: Because none might enter clothed with sackcloth
Because he was not invited
Because the gate was closed
Because he was not a royal official
questions.correctAnswer: Because none might enter clothed with sackcloth
questions.explanation: Esther 4:2 explains that none might enter into the king's gate clothed with sackcloth, which is why Mordecai could not enter.

questions.question: What was happening among the Jews in every province where the king's decree came?
options: Great mourning, fasting, weeping, and wailing
Celebrations and feasts
Building altars
Offering sacrifices
questions.correctAnswer: Great mourning, fasting, weeping, and wailing
questions.explanation: Esther 4:3 describes great mourning, fasting, weeping, and wailing among the Jews in every province where the king's decree came.

questions.question: How did Esther react when her maids told her what Mordecai had done?
options: She was exceedingly grieved
She ignored the news
She immediately went to the king
She rejoiced
questions.correctAnswer: She was exceedingly grieved
questions.explanation: According to Esther 4:4, Esther was exceedingly grieved when her maids told her what Mordecai had done.

questions.question: What did Esther send to Mordecai after hearing about his mourning?
options: Raiment to clothe him
Food and drink
A message of encouragement
A letter to the king
questions.correctAnswer: Raiment to clothe him
questions.explanation: Esther 4:4 states that she sent raiment to clothe Mordecai and take away his sackcloth.

questions.question: Who did Esther send to find out why Mordecai was in mourning?
options: Hatach, one of the king's chamberlains
Haman
The king's guards
Her maids
questions.correctAnswer: Hatach, one of the king's chamberlains
questions.explanation: Esther 4:5 shows Esther called for Hatach to learn why Mordecai was in mourning.

questions.question: What did Mordecai tell Hatach about the king's decree?
options: That Haman had promised money to destroy the Jews
That the king was unaware
That Esther was in danger
That the decree was to protect the Jews
questions.correctAnswer: That Haman had promised money to destroy the Jews
questions.explanation: Esther 4:7 states Mordecai told Hatach about the sum of money Haman had promised to destroy the Jews.

questions.question: What did Mordecai give Hatach to show Esther?
options: A copy of the king's decree to destroy the Jews
A letter from the king
A royal scepter
A sword
questions.correctAnswer: A copy of the king's decree to destroy the Jews
questions.explanation: Esther 4:8 explains Mordecai gave Hatach the copy of the writing of the decree given at Shushan to destroy the Jews.

questions.question: According to Esther, what was the penalty for coming to the king uncalled?
options: Death unless the king holds out the golden scepter
Imprisonment
Fines
Exile
questions.correctAnswer: Death unless the king holds out the golden scepter
questions.explanation: Esther 4:11 states the law that anyone who comes to the king uncalled shall be put to death unless the king extends the golden scepter.

questions.question: True or False: Esther had been called to come to the king for thirty days.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 4:11 states she had not been called to come unto the king for these thirty days.

questions.question: What did Mordecai tell Esther about her safety in the king's house?
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 4:13 says Mordecai told Esther not to think she would escape in the king's house more than all the Jews.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Mordecai said, 'Who knoweth whether thou art come to the kingdom for such a ______ as this?'
options: time
reason
day
purpose
questions.correctAnswer: time
questions.explanation: Esther 4:14 contains the phrase 'who knoweth whether thou art come to the kingdom for such a time as this?'

questions.question: What did Esther command the Jews to do before she went to the king?
options: Fast for three days and nights
Prepare a feast
Go to battle
Write letters
questions.correctAnswer: Fast for three days and nights
questions.explanation: Esther 4:16 shows Esther commanded all Jews in Shushan to fast for three days and nights before she went to the king.

questions.question: True or False: Esther was willing to risk her life by going to the king without being called.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Esther 4:16 states, 'if I perish, I perish,' showing she was willing to risk her life.

medium.title: Esther Chapter 4 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Esther Chapter 4 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does Esther 4 teach us about the importance of expressing grief and seeking God in times of crisis?
options: By showing Mordecai rent his clothes, put on sackcloth and ashes, and cried aloud in the city
By instructing Esther to immediately confront Haman without prayer
By encouraging the Jews to celebrate despite the decree
By advising to ignore the king's decree and move on
questions.correctAnswer: By showing Mordecai rent his clothes, put on sackcloth and ashes, and cried aloud in the city
questions.explanation: Esther 4:1-3 shows Mordecai's response to the crisis—mourning with sackcloth and ashes, crying out loudly, and the Jews fasting and weeping. This illustrates the biblical virtue of expressing grief and turning to God in prayer during trials.

questions.question: A fellow believer is hesitant to pray for others openly. Based on Esther 4, what biblical truth would you share?
options: Interceding for others is necessary even when it is difficult or risky
Prayer should only be private and never involve fasting
Only the king's servants are allowed to pray publicly
Prayer has no impact on difficult situations
questions.correctAnswer: Interceding for others is necessary even when it is difficult or risky
questions.explanation: Esther 4:8-16 reveals Mordecai urging Esther to intercede for her people despite the danger of approaching the king uninvited. Esther responds by calling for fasting and prayer, demonstrating the importance of bold intercession.

questions.question: What does Esther 4 teach about obedience and trusting God's timing in difficult circumstances?
options: Esther obeyed Mordecai's command to fast and prepare before approaching the king
Esther ignored Mordecai's advice and acted impulsively
Mordecai told Esther to wait without action
Esther avoided the king to stay safe
questions.correctAnswer: Esther obeyed Mordecai's command to fast and prepare before approaching the king
questions.explanation: Esther 4:15-17 shows Esther instructing the Jews to fast and committing herself to the same discipline before facing the king, highlighting faith, obedience, and reliance on God's timing.

questions.question: How does Mordecai’s refusal to remove his sackcloth in Esther 4 demonstrate biblical humility and perseverance?
options: He chose to remain in sackcloth despite Esther’s offer to clothe him
He quickly accepted Esther’s raiment to appear before the king
He abandoned mourning to celebrate
He ignored the crisis
questions.correctAnswer: He chose to remain in sackcloth despite Esther’s offer to clothe him
questions.explanation: Esther 4:4 shows Mordecai’s refusal to remove his sackcloth, symbolizing humility, steadfastness, and perseverance in mourning and prayer during distressing times.

questions.question: Based on Esther 4, what can we learn about the role of communication and fellowship in the church during trials?
options: Esther's maids informed her about Mordecai’s mourning, showing the importance of sharing burdens
Esther remained isolated without counsel
Mordecai kept his grief secret
The Jews ignored one another
questions.correctAnswer: Esther's maids informed her about Mordecai’s mourning, showing the importance of sharing burdens
questions.explanation: Esther 4:4-5 illustrates how Esther’s attendants communicated Mordecai’s distress to her, emphasizing fellowship and mutual support in difficult times.

questions.question: In Esther 4, what does Mordecai’s charge to Esther about her responsibility teach us regarding courage and faithfulness?
options: That she should not expect to escape because of her position, but act for her people
That she could remain silent and safe
That only the king can save the Jews
That she should abandon her people
questions.correctAnswer: That she should not expect to escape because of her position, but act for her people
questions.explanation: Esther 4:13-14 contains Mordecai’s exhortation reminding Esther that her royal position is a divine appointment to act courageously for her people’s deliverance.

questions.question: How does Esther’s willingness to risk her life for her people in Esther 4 teach us about sacrificial love and commitment?
options: She declares, 'If I perish, I perish,' showing readiness to sacrifice for others
She chooses to protect herself only
She ignores her people’s plight
She demands the king’s permission first
questions.correctAnswer: She declares, 'If I perish, I perish,' showing readiness to sacrifice for others
questions.explanation: Esther 4:16 reveals her resolve to approach the king despite the law, exemplifying sacrificial love and commitment to God's people.

questions.question: True or False: According to Esther 4, fasting and prayer are powerful spiritual disciplines when facing trials and decisions.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The text in Esther 4:3 and 16 shows the Jews fasting and weeping, and Esther calling for a three-day fast, highlighting fasting and prayer as vital spiritual responses.

questions.question: True or False: Esther was immediately allowed to enter the king’s court without being called, according to Esther 4.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 4:11 explains the law that anyone entering the king’s inner court without being called could be put to death unless the king extends his golden sceptre, and Esther had not been called for thirty days.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Mordecai told Esther to ________ because deliverance for the Jews will arise from another place if she keeps silent.
options: not keep silent
avoid action
leave the kingdom
seek revenge
questions.correctAnswer: not keep silent
questions.explanation: Esther 4:14 records Mordecai’s command that Esther must speak up and act, or deliverance will come elsewhere but she and her family may perish.

questions.question: How does Esther 4 teach about trusting God's providence in leadership and circumstances?
options: It suggests that Esther’s rise was for “such a time as this,” implying divine purpose
It states that success depends only on human effort
It advises ignoring God’s hand in events
It emphasizes avoiding responsibility
questions.correctAnswer: It suggests that Esther’s rise was for “such a time as this,” implying divine purpose
questions.explanation: Esther 4:14 highlights the belief that God places people in positions for specific purposes, encouraging trust in His providence.

questions.question: What does Mordecai’s action of sending a copy of the king’s decree to Esther teach about honesty and transparency in difficult situations?
options: It shows the importance of sharing critical information to enable informed action
It encourages hiding bad news
It suggests ignoring threats
It advocates secrecy at all costs
questions.correctAnswer: It shows the importance of sharing critical information to enable informed action
questions.explanation: Esther 4:7-8 reveals Mordecai sending the decree so Esther understands the full danger, reflecting honesty and responsibility.

questions.question: How does the chapter illustrate the role of spiritual discipline in preparing to face challenges?
options: Esther and her maidens fasted for three days before approaching the king
Esther immediately approached the king without preparation
Mordecai told Esther to eat and drink normally
The Jews celebrated instead of fasting
questions.correctAnswer: Esther and her maidens fasted for three days before approaching the king
questions.explanation: Esther 4:16 emphasizes fasting as spiritual preparation, showing reliance on God when confronting difficult tasks.

questions.question: What practical lesson about leadership and responsibility can be drawn from Esther 4?
options: Leaders must sometimes risk personal safety for the good of their people
Leaders should avoid conflict at all costs
Leadership means avoiding responsibility
Leaders only serve themselves
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must sometimes risk personal safety for the good of their people
questions.explanation: Esther 4:14-16 demonstrates Esther’s acceptance of risk in leadership for the salvation of her people, teaching responsibility.

questions.question: According to Esther 4, what role does community support play in spiritual battles and trials?
options: The Jews fasted together in unity to support Esther and seek God’s help
Individuals should face struggles alone
Community has no role in spiritual matters
Fasting is only a personal act
questions.correctAnswer: The Jews fasted together in unity to support Esther and seek God’s help
questions.explanation: Esther 4:3,16 depicts the Jews fasting and mourning together, underscoring the strength found in communal spiritual discipline.

hard.title: Esther Chapter 4 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Esther Chapter 4.

questions.question: What symbolic act did Mordecai perform to express his grief over the decree against the Jews?
options: Rented his clothes and wore sackcloth with ashes
Offered a burnt sacrifice
Fasted for seven days
Sang a lamentation in the city square
questions.correctAnswer: Rented his clothes and wore sackcloth with ashes
questions.explanation: Esther 4:1 states that Mordecai rent his clothes and put on sackcloth with ashes, a common ancient Near Eastern expression of mourning and repentance.

questions.question: Why was Mordecai unable to enter the king's gate while wearing sackcloth?
options: Because none might enter clothed with sackcloth
Because he was not summoned by the king
Because he was a Jew and forbidden
Because the gate was closed for a festival
questions.correctAnswer: Because none might enter clothed with sackcloth
questions.explanation: Esther 4:2 explains that no one was allowed to enter the king's gate wearing sackcloth, reflecting the sacredness and protocol of the royal court.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the response of the Jewish people throughout the provinces upon hearing the king's decree?
options: Great mourning, fasting, weeping, wailing, and wearing sackcloth and ashes
Celebrations and feasts to seek God's favor
Marching to the palace to petition the king
Quiet submission without public display
questions.correctAnswer: Great mourning, fasting, weeping, wailing, and wearing sackcloth and ashes
questions.explanation: Esther 4:3 records the widespread mourning and fasting among the Jews, indicating communal grief and desperate supplication.

questions.question: What was Esther's initial reaction when she was informed of Mordecai's mourning?
options: She was exceedingly grieved and sent raiment to clothe Mordecai
She immediately went to the king to intercede
She ignored the news fearing for her own safety
She called for Haman to explain the decree
questions.correctAnswer: She was exceedingly grieved and sent raiment to clothe Mordecai
questions.explanation: According to Esther 4:4, Esther was very sorrowful and tried to comfort Mordecai by sending him garments to replace his sackcloth, which he refused.

questions.question: Who did Esther send to Mordecai to inquire about the cause of his mourning?
options: Hatach, one of the king's chamberlains
Haman, the king's advisor
The king's scribe
A royal guard
questions.correctAnswer: Hatach, one of the king's chamberlains
questions.explanation: Esther 4:5 states that Esther called for Hatach to find out why Mordecai was mourning in such a manner.

questions.question: What critical information did Mordecai reveal to Esther through Hatach?
options: The decree to destroy all Jews and Haman’s bribe to the king
The king's secret plans for war
The identity of the new queen
The king’s illness and need for Esther's prayers
questions.correctAnswer: The decree to destroy all Jews and Haman’s bribe to the king
questions.explanation: Esther 4:7 tells that Mordecai informed Esther about the decree and the money Haman promised to pay to eliminate the Jews.

questions.question: What was the significance of the written decree given at Shushan that Mordecai gave to Esther?
options: It was the official order to destroy the Jews, urging Esther to intercede
It was a royal invitation for Esther to visit the king
It was a peace treaty with neighboring nations
It was an edict granting Esther new authority
questions.correctAnswer: It was the official order to destroy the Jews, urging Esther to intercede
questions.explanation: In Esther 4:8, Mordecai gave Esther a copy of the decree to inform her fully and charge her to plead for their people.

questions.question: What was Esther's response regarding her ability to approach the king after hearing Mordecai's message?
options: She had not been called to the king for thirty days and risked death if she came uninvited
She was confident she could enter the king’s presence anytime
She planned to confront Haman first
She requested a royal pardon before approaching
questions.correctAnswer: She had not been called to the king for thirty days and risked death if she came uninvited
questions.explanation: Esther 4:11 explains the law forbidding uncalled appearances before the king, with death as penalty unless the king extends his golden scepter.

questions.question: What theological principle is highlighted by Mordecai’s assertion that deliverance for the Jews will come from another place if Esther remains silent?
options: Divine sovereignty and providence in salvation
Human effort alone can prevent disaster
Fate is fixed and cannot be changed
Only royal decrees determine outcomes
questions.correctAnswer: Divine sovereignty and providence in salvation
questions.explanation: Esther 4:14 implies that God’s deliverance is not limited to one person, reflecting the biblical theme of God’s providential care beyond human agency.

questions.question: Mordecai’s message to Esther includes the question, 'Who knoweth whether thou art come to the kingdom for such a time as this?' What literary device is this an example of?
options: Rhetorical question
Simile
Hyperbole
Metaphor
questions.correctAnswer: Rhetorical question
questions.explanation: This question in Esther 4:14 is rhetorical, meant to emphasize Esther's potential divine appointment without expecting a direct answer.

questions.question: What act of faith did Esther command the Jews to perform before she would approach the king?
options: A three-day fast with no food or water
Public prayer in the temple
Sacrificial offerings at the altar
A pilgrimage to Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: A three-day fast with no food or water
questions.explanation: Esther 4:16 records Esther’s instruction to fast for three days and nights without eating or drinking as a preparation for her risky approach to the king.

questions.question: What is the significance of Esther’s statement, 'If I perish, I perish' in the context of ancient Near Eastern royal protocol?
options: It reflects her acceptance of the possible fatal consequences of approaching the king uninvited
It signifies her intention to rebel against the king
It means she plans to leave the kingdom
It indicates she will seek revenge on Haman
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects her acceptance of the possible fatal consequences of approaching the king uninvited
questions.explanation: Esther 4:16 shows her courage and resignation to the law that could sentence her to death if the king did not grant favor.

questions.question: How does the motif of fasting in Esther 4:3 and 4:16 connect with the broader biblical theme of seeking divine intervention?
options: Fasting is a means of humbling oneself and seeking God's favor in times of crisis
Fasting is used to gain political power
Fasting replaces prayer in biblical practice
Fasting is a sign of mourning only with no spiritual implications
questions.correctAnswer: Fasting is a means of humbling oneself and seeking God's favor in times of crisis
questions.explanation: The use of fasting in Esther reflects a biblical pattern found elsewhere (e.g., Daniel 9, Joel 2) where fasting accompanies prayer to seek God's mercy and help.

questions.question: True or False: Mordecai immediately accepted Esther's offer to clothe him and remove his sackcloth.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Esther 4:4 states that Mordecai did not accept the raiment sent by Esther, choosing to remain in sackcloth as a sign of mourning.

questions.question: What role does Hatach serve in the communication between Esther and Mordecai?
options: He acts as a messenger and intermediary
He is a military commander
He is the king’s advisor
He is Esther’s rival
questions.correctAnswer: He acts as a messenger and intermediary
questions.explanation: Esther 4:5-9 shows Hatach carrying messages between Esther and Mordecai, facilitating crucial communication during the crisis.

theological.title: Esther Chapter 4 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Esther Chapter 4 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What initial reaction did Mordecai have when he perceived the decree against the Jews?
options: He rent his clothes and put on sackcloth with ashes
He immediately went to the king to plead
He gathered the Jews to fight
He prayed silently at home
questions.correctAnswer: He rent his clothes and put on sackcloth with ashes
questions.explanation: Mordecai's response was to mourn publicly by renting his clothes and wearing sackcloth and ashes, signifying repentance and grief as described in Esther 4:1. This act reflects the biblical motif of mourning in sackcloth and ashes seen also in Jonah 3:6, Daniel 9:3, Joel 2:12, and Job 2:12.

questions.question: Why could Mordecai not enter the king's gate while wearing sackcloth?
options: None might enter into the king's gate clothed with sackcloth
He was not summoned by the king
He feared for his life
The gate was closed for the day
questions.correctAnswer: None might enter into the king's gate clothed with sackcloth
questions.explanation: The law forbade anyone to enter the king's gate wearing sackcloth, a sign of mourning, as stated in Esther 4:2. This reflects the strict royal protocols and the respect for the majesty of the king, similar to how sacred spaces require purity in Exodus 19:12-13 and Leviticus 10:1-3.

questions.question: What was the general response of the Jews throughout the provinces upon hearing the king's decree?
options: Great mourning, fasting, weeping, wailing, sackcloth and ashes
Celebration and feasting
Rebellion against the decree
Silence and fear
questions.correctAnswer: Great mourning, fasting, weeping, wailing, sackcloth and ashes
questions.explanation: The text in Esther 4:3 describes a profound communal response of mourning and fasting, expressions of repentance and reliance on God, akin to the responses in Joel 2:15-16, Nehemiah 9:1-3, Ezra 8:21, and Psalm 35:13.

questions.question: How did Queen Esther respond when she was informed of Mordecai's condition?
options: She was exceedingly grieved and sent raiment to clothe Mordecai
She ignored the news
She immediately went to the king
She called for Haman
questions.correctAnswer: She was exceedingly grieved and sent raiment to clothe Mordecai
questions.explanation: Esther showed compassion and concern by sending clothes to Mordecai to remove his sackcloth, but he refused, highlighting the seriousness of the situation (Esther 4:4). This reflects Christian charity and care for others (Galatians 6:2; James 2:15-16).

questions.question: Who was Hatach and what role did he play in this chapter?
options: One of the king’s chamberlains sent by Esther to Mordecai
The chief priest offering sacrifices
The king’s messenger announcing Haman’s decree
A Jewish elder leading prayers
questions.correctAnswer: One of the king’s chamberlains sent by Esther to Mordecai
questions.explanation: Hatach was a trusted attendant of Esther, serving as the mediator who carried messages between Esther and Mordecai (Esther 4:5-6). This role is reminiscent of biblical intermediaries like the prophets who conveyed God’s messages (e.g., Elijah in 1 Kings 18).

questions.question: What critical information did Mordecai convey to Esther through Hatach?
options: The decree to destroy the Jews and the bribe Haman offered
The king’s plan to promote Mordecai
The arrival of foreign armies
The death of the king
questions.correctAnswer: The decree to destroy the Jews and the bribe Haman offered
questions.explanation: Mordecai informed Esther about the deadly decree against the Jews and Haman's bribe to the king’s treasury (Esther 4:7), showing the gravity of the threat and the political corruption involved. This echoes themes of injustice and the need for intervention seen in Exodus 3:7-8 and Daniel 6:6-9.

questions.question: What did Mordecai urge Esther to do after informing her of the decree?
options: Go in unto the king to make supplication and request for her people
Hide herself for safety
Send a letter to the king
Lead a public revolt
questions.correctAnswer: Go in unto the king to make supplication and request for her people
questions.explanation: Mordecai charged Esther to courageously approach the king with a plea for her people’s salvation (Esther 4:8), displaying themes of intercession and advocacy that are central to biblical mediation (Exodus 32:11-14; 1 Timothy 2:1-4).

questions.question: What law did Esther refer to that made her hesitant to approach the king without being summoned?
options: Anyone who comes to the king uncalled shall be put to death unless the king extends the golden sceptre
Only men may approach the king
No one may approach the king on feast days
Only those with royal blood may approach the king
questions.correctAnswer: Anyone who comes to the king uncalled shall be put to death unless the king extends the golden sceptre
questions.explanation: Esther explained the law that unauthorized entry to the king's inner court was punishable by death unless the king granted favor with his golden sceptre (Esther 4:11). This underscores the seriousness of royal protocol and foreshadows Christ as the Mediator granting access to God (Hebrews 4:16; John 14:6).

questions.question: What was Mordecai's response to Esther's hesitation to approach the king?
options: Think not that thou shalt escape in the king's house more than all the Jews
Wait for another opportunity
Send another messenger to the king
Renounce her position as queen
questions.correctAnswer: Think not that thou shalt escape in the king's house more than all the Jews
questions.explanation: Mordecai rebuked Esther, emphasizing that her safety was not guaranteed even as queen and that she had a divine purpose for such a time as this (Esther 4:13-14), illustrating God's providence and divine calling evident throughout Scripture (Romans 8:28; Jeremiah 29:11).

questions.question: What theological principle is expressed in Mordecai’s statement, 'who knoweth whether thou art come to the kingdom for such a time as this'?
options: Divine providence and purpose in human history
Random chance and fate
Human effort alone determines outcomes
The king’s decree is absolute
questions.correctAnswer: Divine providence and purpose in human history
questions.explanation: Mordecai’s statement reflects the doctrine of providence, that God sovereignly places individuals in positions for His purposes, a theme echoed in Genesis 50:20, Romans 8:28, and Acts 17:26-27.

questions.question: What specific action did Esther command the Jews to undertake before she approached the king?
options: To fast for three days and nights without eating or drinking
To prepare a feast in her honor
To arm themselves for battle
To write letters of petition
questions.correctAnswer: To fast for three days and nights without eating or drinking
questions.explanation: Esther instructed a fast of three days and nights for all Jews in Shushan, including herself and her maidens, demonstrating reliance on God’s intervention through prayer and fasting (Esther 4:16). This mirrors fasting practices in Daniel 9:3, Joel 2:15, Matthew 6:16-18, and Acts 13:2-3.

questions.question: What was Esther’s declaration about her willingness to approach the king, despite the risk?
options: If I perish, I perish
I will only go if the king calls me
I will send a letter instead
I refuse to go
questions.correctAnswer: If I perish, I perish
questions.explanation: Esther expressed her resolute faith and submission to God's will with the declaration 'If I perish, I perish' (Esther 4:16), reflecting the biblical theme of trusting God even unto death (Daniel 3:17-18; Hebrews 11:35-38).

questions.question: What does Mordecai’s refusal to accept the raiment sent by Esther symbolize in a theological context?
options: His commitment to mourning and intercession for the people
His rejection of Esther’s authority
His desire to rebel against the king
His acceptance of death
questions.correctAnswer: His commitment to mourning and intercession for the people
questions.explanation: Mordecai’s refusal to remove sackcloth reflects a steadfast commitment to repentance and intercession (Esther 4:4), highlighting the biblical role of persistent prayer and sorrow for sin as seen in Nehemiah 1:4, Psalm 35:13, Jonah 3:5-9, and 2 Chronicles 7:14.

questions.question: What does Esther’s willingness to risk death by approaching the king reveal about her character and faith?
options: She demonstrates courage and trust in God’s providence
She acts out of selfish ambition
She disregards the law carelessly
She seeks to overthrow the king
questions.correctAnswer: She demonstrates courage and trust in God’s providence
questions.explanation: Esther’s determination to approach the king despite the law’s penalty shows her courageous faith and submission to God’s sovereign plan (Esther 4:16). This aligns with biblical examples of faithful courage such as David (1 Samuel 17), Daniel (Daniel 6), and Paul (Acts 27:23-25).

questions.question: How does the communal fasting commanded by Esther reflect broader biblical themes about human response to crisis?
options: It shows dependence on God’s deliverance through repentance and prayer
It indicates weakness and despair
It is a political strategy to gain favor
It is a form of protest against the king
questions.correctAnswer: It shows dependence on God’s deliverance through repentance and prayer
questions.explanation: Communal fasting signifies earnest repentance and reliance on God’s mercy during crisis, a recurring biblical response (Joel 2:12-17; Esther 4:16; Jonah 3:5-10; Ezra 8:21). It expresses humility and hope in divine intervention rather than human power.
